instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Is this dead CPU - 0.5V 0.01A Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line
Removed the fuses and injected 1V, CPU glares up. Customer needs data desperatly.

[ATTACH type="full"]60873[/ATTACH]

Dead CPU?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Is this dead CPU - 0.5V 0.01A Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Very likely...

How many times need someone to tell you STOP to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in this manner.
Don't say 1V is safe voltage; just a childish excuse.
You only need ohm scale measurment to detect CPU power supply problem; why to inject voltage first???

Now find the burnt CPU power supply chip and check VCORE resistance to ground, after removed it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Is this dead CPU - 0.5V 0.01A Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I just got <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with the same type of short circuit on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line, and 1V injection detected a shorted cap on the audio line.

I agree with what you said, but can we clarify what internal ohm shortage or case scenarios we should look for before any injection? Even on low voltages. Removing all CPU GPU MOSFETs/Coils before any injection surely is not cost-effective.

We surely cannot open a new thread each time we want to diagnose a short.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Is this dead CPU - 0.5V 0.01A Short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You don't need to completely remove anything.
Once you detect the short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and any big coil, just lift (one side) the corresponding coil.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> resistance to ground should go up then.
Be aware, CPU and GPU have 2-3 coils for the same rail, so need to lift all common coils.

In some cases (rarely), the burnt chip/MOSFET cause short to ground too.
Lifting coils don't help like above then.
